text: - Welcome back to this

"AWS TechShift: Migrate and
Modernize" video miniseries.

These videos are aimed at
independent software vendors
who are currently on premise and looking
to migrate to the cloud.
It's also aimed at those that are looking
to modernize the architecture

of an existing application
to become more cloud native.

In the last video, we
explored the benefits
of migrating to the cloud

and also introduced our
monolithic photo gallery
as a case study application.

In this video, we are going
to explore the concept
of a landing zone and look at how to build
our virtual private cloud, or our VPC,
which will form the base network
of our application resources.
(upbeat music)
When starting out in AWS,

customers are faced with
many design decisions.
For example, do you have one AWS account

or split out into multiple
separate accounts?
If you choose to use multiple accounts,

are these separated by
team, by environment
or by application?
Other decisions include how to give access

to the account, how to
structure the networking,

how to implement logging,
auditing, and security guardrails.
When you start out with an AWS account,
there is nothing in it,
no resources, no users, no controls.

It is up to you to put together
your own starting baseline.
This is called a landing zone.
To help customers quickly establish

a multi-account landing zone
following AWS best practices,

we created a service
called AWS Control Tower.
Control Tower automates the work involved
in setting up a landing zone.
Control Tower is opinionated guidance
on what the landing zone should look like,

delivered as a service in
the console developed by AWS.
Control Tower takes best practices
and makes it very simple to deploy
all of these automatically.
The Control Tower automated landing zone

enables and configures AWS
Cloud Trail and AWS Config
to log to an Amazon S3 bucket
located in a log archive account.

It also provides federated
access to accounts
using AWS Single Sign-On.

It enables guardrails to
protect the resources deployed
by AWS Control Tower

and detects non-compliance
across multiple accounts.
Finally, it supports lifecycle events,
which allows you to configure
any additional custom automation
as part of a new account creation,

such as your default
network configuration.

You can then build out your
multi-account environment
from this starting baseline

and begin provisioning
your application resources.
Now we have used Control Tower
to configure our landing zone.

Let's go back to our
photo gallery application.
Before we can provision our EC2 instance
to run our application,

we first need to build
a VPC which will contain
the networking constructs and subnets.

A VPC is created in a
particular AWS region
and given an IP CIDR range.

In this case, we've created
the VPC in eu-west-1,
which is in Ireland
and given a 10.0.0.0/16 CIDR range.
This means any resources provisioned

inside the VPC must be
within this IP range.
Multiple VPCs can be created
within a region within an AWS account.
But in this example, we will just use one.
Within each AWS region,
there are multiple availability zones.
In this case, there are three.
Inside a VPC, you can provision subnets.
A subnet cannot span availability zones
so we must create multiple subnets,

in this case, one for
each availability zone.

An internet gateway can
be attached to a VPC

to allow access in and
out of the internet.

This will allow end users
to access our application.
So far, we have introduced public subnets,

which have a route directly
to the internet gateway.

We are now adding in
additional private subnets,
again, one for each availability zone,

which will not have a route
to the internet gateway.

Instead, to allow resources
in the private subnets
to still access the internet,

we will provision NAT
gateways in the public subnets
and add a route from the private subnets
to those NAT gateways.
The NAT gateway means that traffic

can get out to the internet for
things like software patches

but won't allow access to
resources from the internet.

The private subnets are now
ready for our database layer,

something that we will
look at in more detail
in the next video.
Join us in the next video to explore
replatforming in database layer

and to optimize the delivery
of static web content.
(upbeat music)
